online for a few brief moments though we
Glimpse the future a future where

a

ordinary people have voice not just

traditional
hierarchy voice and power are shifting

where you are today and Mark Zuckerberg

old as the world becomes more connected

traditional career paths are shifting as
well in 2001 after working in the

to try to find a job my timing wasn't

small companies were closing big
companies were laying people off one
woman CEO looked at me and said we would
never even think about hiring someone
like
you after a while I had a few offers and
I had to make a decision so what did I

and compared the companies and the

roles one of the jobs on that sheet was

Google had no business unit so what was
there to generally
manage and the job was several levels
lower than jobs I was being offered at
other
companies so I sat down with Eric
Schmidt who had just become the CEO and

this job meets none of my criteria he
put his hand on my sheet and he looked
at me and he said don't be an idiot
excellent career
advice and then he said get on a rocket

and they're having a lot of impact
careers take care of themselves and when

missions don't matter as much that's
when stagnation and politics come in if
you're offered a seat on a rocket ship
don't ask what seat just get
on about 6 and a half years later when I

coo at the time people said why are you
going to work for a
23-year-old the traditional metaphor for

think that metaphor holds it doesn't
make sense in a less hierarchical world
when I was first at Facebook a woman
named Lori goer a 1997 graduate of HBS
was working in marketing at eBay and I

you know talk to you about coming to

about calling you and telling you all

everyone's doing that so instead I want
to know what's your biggest problem and
how can I solve it my jaw Hit the Floor
I've hired thousands of people up to
that point in my career but no one had
ever said anything like that and I had
never said anything like that job
searches are always about the job
searcher
but not in Lor's case I said you're

and you can solve it so Lor changed
Fields into something she never thought

and runs all of the people operations at
Facebook and is doing an extraordinary
job having amazing impact Lori has a
great metaphor for careers she says
they're not a ladder they're a jungle
gym as you you start your PO a post HBS
career look for opportunities look for
growth look for impact look for Mission
move sideways move down move on move off
build your skills not your
resume evaluate what you can do not the

work take a sales quota a line roll an
Ops job don't plan too much much and
don't expect a direct climb if I had
mapped out my career when I was sitting
where you are I would have missed my
career you are entering a different
business world than I
entered mine was just starting to get
connected yours is
hyperconnected mine was competitive
yours is way more competitive mine moved
quickly yours moves even more
quickly as traditional structures are
breaking down leadership has to evolve
as well from hierarchy to Shared
responsibility from command and control
to listening and
guiding you've been trained by this
great institution not just to be part of
these Trends but to
lead as you lead in this new world you
will not be able to rely on who you are

rely on what you know your strength will
not come from your place on some or
chart your strength will come from
building building trust and earning

more than anything else you're going to

authentically to speak so that you
inspire the people around you and to
listen so that you continue to learn
each and every day on the
job if you watch young children you'll

my friend Betsy in my section A few

butt
as adults we are never this honest and

made but it's not always a good thing

say well I think there are many good

WTF truth is better served by using

please and then she said it again and he

simpler please and so on and so on
finally in sheer exasperation she bursts
out my manager is
bad simple and clear and super important
for him to
know people rarely speak this clearly in

joined Facebook one of the things I had
to do was build a business side of the
company put some systems into place but
I wanted to do it without destroying the
culture that made Facebook great and so
one of the things I tried to do was
encourage people not to do formal

with me and I would say things like
don't do PowerPoint presentations for

but everyone ignored me and they kept
doing their PowerPoint presentations
meeting after meeting month after month
so about two years in I said okay I hate
rules but I have a rule no more
PowerPoint in my meetings and I mean it
no
more so about a month
later I went out and I was about to

really should know everyone's pretty

clients thing
and I said what no PowerPoint with

made a rule no
PowerPoint so I got on the stage and

but two more importantly next time you

don't adhere to it fight it or ignore it
even if you think it's coming from me or
Mark a good leader recognizes that most
people won't feel comfortable
challenging Authority so it falls upon
authority to encourage them to question
it's easy to say that you're going to
encourage feedback but it's hard to do
because unfortunately it doesn't always
come in the format we want to hear it
when I first started at Google I had a
team of four people and it was really
important to me that I interview
everyone who was on my team it felt like
being part of my team meant I had to
know you when the team had gotten to
about a 100 people I realized it was
taking longer to schedule my interviews
so one day in my meeting of just my
direct reports I said maybe I should
stop interviewing fully expecting them
to jump in and say oh no your interviews
are a critical part of the process they
applauded and then they fell all over
themselves explaining that I was you
know the bottleneck of all
time I was embarrassed and then I was
angry and I spent a few hours just
quietly fuming why didn't they tell me I
was a bottleneck why did they let me go
on slowing them down and then I realized
that if they hadn't told me that was my
fault I hadn't been open enough told
them I wanted that feedback and I would
have to change that going
forward when you're the leader it is
really hard to get good feedback and
honest feedback no matter how many times
you ask for it one trick I've discovered
is I try to speak really openly about
the things I'm bad at because that gives
people permission to agree with me which
is a lot easier than pointing it out in
the first place so to take one of many
possible examples when things are
unresolved I can get a tad
anxious really when anything's
unresolved I get a lot anxious I'm quite
certain no one has ever accused me of
being too
calm so I speak about it openly and that
gives people permission to tell me when
it's happening but if I never said
anything would anyone who work at fa
works at Facebook walk up to me and say
and say hey Cheryl calm down you're
driving us all nuts I don't think so
as you graduate today ask yourselves how
will you lead will you use simple and
clear language will you seek out honest
feedback when you get honest feedback
will you react with anger or with
gratitude as we strive to be more
authentic in our communication we should
also strive to be more authentic in a
broader sense I talk a lot about
bringing your whole self to work
something I believe in very deeply
motivation comes from working on things
we care about but it also comes from
working with people we care about and in
order to care about someone you have to
know them you have to know what they
love and hate what they feel not just
what they think if you want to win
hearts and Minds you have to lead with
your heart as well as your mind I don't
believe we have a professional self from
Mondays through Fridays and a real self
for the rest of the time that kind of
division probably never worked but in
today's world of real voice and
authentic voice it makes even less sense
I've cried at work I've told people I've
cried at work and this got reported in

Mark Zuckerberg shoulder which is not
exactly what
happened I talk about my hopes and fears
and I ask people about theirs I try to
be myself honest about my strengths and

the
same it is all professional and it is
all personal all at the very same
time as part of bringing my whole self
to work I recently started speaking up
about the challenges women face in the

before this I did my career like
everyone else does it I never told
anyone I was a girl don't tell I left
the lights on when I went home to do
something for my kids I locked my office
door and pumped milk for my babies while
I was on conference calls and people
would say what is that sound I'd say
what sound I hear a beep oh there's a

office but the lack of progress progress
we've made in the past decade has
convinced me that we need to start
talking about
this I graduated from HBS in
1995 and I thought it was completely
clear that by the time someone from my
year was invited to speak at this Podium
we would have achieved equality in the
workforce but women at the top sea level
jobs is stuck at 15 or 16% and has not
moved in a decade not even close to 50%
and worse no longer
growing we need to acknowledge openly
that gender remains an issue at the
highest levels of
leadership the promise of equality is
not
equality we need to start talking about
this we need to start talking about how
women underestimate their abilities
compared to men and for women but not
men success and likability are
negatively correlated that means that as
a woman is more successful in your

means that women need a different form

and some protection in some ways more
than men
and there aren't enough senior women out

why we need to start talking openly
about the flexibility all of us need to

leave the office at 5:30 to have dinner
with my children and I was shocked at

says she wasn't sure I could get more

axe I told her I wasn't really

that but this showed me that this is an

jobs we will not close the leadership
Gap until we close the professional
ambition Gap we need more women not just

take their rightful seats at the head of
the
table one of the reasons I was so

noria told that this year is the 50th
50th anniversary of letting women into

about getting more women into leadership

made sense but they left the urinals in
she thought the message was super clear
we're not sure this whole girl thing is

critical to your future success and
we're public now so can you click on an
ad or two while you're
there
two that you make the effort to speak as
well as seek the
truth
three that you remain true to and open
about your authentic
self and four most
deeply that your generation accomplishes
what mine has failed to do give us a

better
world I join everyone here in offering

give yourselves a huge round of
